ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS



2.39 p.m.
ADVERTISEMENT ON FOUNTAIN AT AIRPORT


    1. Mr Teong Eng Siong asked the Deputy Prime Minister why a firm has been allowed to incorporate an advertisement in the fountain at the approach to

Column: 422

the Paya Lebar International Airport; whether the firm pays a concession fee for the advertisement, and what is the fee for a year.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, the decision to allow the firm concerned to incorporate an advertisement in the fountain built and paid for by the company at a cost of $69,000 at the approach road to the Paya Lebar International Airport was approved by the Malaysian Ministry of Transport on the 5th July, 1965, when the Department of Civil Aviation was under its control.

    The company does not pay concession fees for the advertisement, but it is responsible for the proper operation and maintenance of the fountain, estimated to cost $5,000 a year, in addition to the cost of electricity and water consumed. At the end of five years, from 1st January, 1966, the fountain and all its fittings will become the property of the Government. As advertising on the fountain has drawn unfavourable comments from visitors to the Airport, negotiations will be taken up to transfer the fountain to the Government within the contract period.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong (Sembawang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, can I raise a supplementary question?

    Mr Speaker: Yes, certainly.

    Mr Teong Eng Siong(In Mandarin): I would like to ask the Minister concerned, since this is a place which many tourists will be visiting, whether we can take immediate steps to remove this advertisement and, instead, other advertisements, posters, or slogans of a national nature be posted there. For instance, we can publicise that we want to build a multi-racial society, or that we welcome all international tourists to come to Singapore.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, as I have pointed out just now, there is a contract by which the Singapore Government has to abide. And as I have indicated to the House, we are now negotiating with the company concerned to transfer the fountain to the Government within five years as soon as

Column: 423

possible, and until we do so we are not in a position to control any advertising slogans which are now located on the fountain itself. However, I am quite certain that the company, being a longstanding company in Singapore, will co-operate with the Government, and I am certain that there will be no difficulties when we come to negotiate with them by which such a transfer can be made to the Government.

Column: 423

ILLEGAL ENTRY OF PERSONS
INTO SINGAPORE


    2. Mr Sim Boon Woo asked the Deputy Prime Minister whether he is aware that there are people entering Singapore illegally along the coast of Mata Ikan and Padang Terbakar, and what action he has taken, or proposes to take, in the matter.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, as long as there was a curfew imposed in Singapore port waters, it was easy to detect any craft making its way to Singapore. With the ending of Indonesian confrontation, the curfew has now been lifted and, as is to be expected, numerous small craft make their way to Singapore from the neighbouring Rhio Islands. Some of these are barter traders who conduct their business at Telok Ayer Basin, while others conceivably bring in illegal immigrants who land at odd spots along the Singa-port coast line.

    The Immigration Department itself does not have a preventive branch to check these illegal entries, but relies on the Ministry of the Interior and Defence for surveillance of our coastal waters. The Immigration Department is liaising with the Ministry of the Interior and Defence on how to improve marine and beach patrols. Immigration and security responsibilities will be integrated when the Immigration Department is transferred to the Ministry of the Interior and Defence from the 1st of January next year. More effective measures to control illegal entries can then be worked out.

Column: 424



    I suggest that the Vigilante Corps in those areas close to the sea can perform a public duty by patrolling the beaches as they did previously, and help to detain illegal entries. From time to time, the presence of illegal immigrants has been reported by public-spirited citizens to the Immigration Department. Raids are conducted and illegal immigrants are deported after serving a term of imprisonment according to the law.

Column: 424

STUDENT DEMONSTRATION OUTSIDE CITY HALL


    3. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister of Defence, in the demonstration by Ngee Ann College students in front of the City Hall on 4th November, 1966, how many Police officers and how many students were injured, and how many students were treated for their injuries at the General Hospital.

    The Minister of State of Defence (Mr Wee Toon Boon) (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, in all, 13 Police officers were injured. One of these, a police constable, was warded at the General Hospital for four days with a 2-inch laceration on his right forehead. Subsequently, 12 days' medical leave were prescribed for him.

    Six students were injured and were treated as outpatients at the General Hospital. The most serious injury among them appeared to be a fractured heel bone and this, on the admission of the student himself, was caused when he jumped from the City Hall steps to the ground in order to avoid the Police.

FROM 1ST JANUARY, 1966

COMMUNITY CENTRE AT 7 M.S. HOLLAND ROAD


    5. Mr Chow Chiok Hock asked the Minister of Defence whether he is aware that the Prime Minister promised to build a community centre at the 7 m.s. Holland Road when he toured the Ulu Pandan Constituency on 13th February, 1966, and when the centre will be built.

    Mr Wee Toon Boon (for the Minister of Defence): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Prime Minister is not in the habit of making promises during his tours of constituencies. What was discussed in Ulu Pandan on the 13th February, 1966, was a proposal to establish a rural type community centre near Yoon Kin Road, off 7½ m.s. Holland Road. This was found to be unsuitable because of the scarcity of population. The Prime Minister advised the Ulu Pandan Citizens Consultative Committee to look for an alternative site. He said that if this site is found suitable, the People's Association would give consideration to the proposal to establish a community centre there. The suitability of this site is being investigated by the People's Association. My preliminary impression is that this locality is also too sparsely populated, there being only 200 families within a radius of two miles of the site. The Citizens Consultative Committee has claimed that there are 500 families. If this site is not suitable, the People's Association will assist in finding another site in the Constituency.

Column: 425

SECOND LANGUAGE IN SECONDARY SCHOOLS


    6. Mr S. Rajoo asked the Minister for Education, in the implementation of the policy of compulsory study of a second language in all secondary schools as from the beginning of 1966, whether (a) teaching facilities for second languages are provided in all Government and Government-aided secondary schools (including Mission schools), and language teachers are available for all the four languages in all the schools, irrespective of the number of students wishing to take a particular language; and (b) all Government-aided secondary

Column: 426

schools (including Mission schools) have been made to implement the policy and commence Tamil language classes, where formerly there were none.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, facilities for teaching any of the four official languages as a second language are provided in all Government and Government-aided schools, including Mission schools. Where second language teachers cannot be fully deployed in one school, they teach in a group of schools. Where the number of pupils choosing a second language is very small, classes are conducted centrally both in the afternoon for morning school pupils and in the morning for afternoon school pupils. It is stressed that, irrespective of the number of students wishing to take a particular second language, adequate provision has been made. All schools have been instructed to implement the policy of a compulsory second language in Secondary I from 1966 and provision has been made for Tamil. This year there are 9 morning and 8 afternoon secondary Tamil class centres, with 17 full-time teachers to teach about 2,500 Tamil pupils. There is also one English secondary school with two part-time Tamil language teachers, one for the morning and one for the afternoon, and two other schools have Tamil language teachers teaching the language during school hours.

    Mr Rajoo (Farrer Park): A supplementary question, Sir. I understand that Tamil classes are centrally run at various places, due to the small number of children taking Tamil as a second language. But my point in bringing up this question here is that each and every school, whether it is a Government or a Government-aided school or a mission school, should be self- sufficient with language teachers in all streams of language, and not depend on any special centres to be provided by Government. I feel that the special centres -

    Mr Speaker: Could the Member frame the supplementary question rather than make a criticism of what the Minister has said?

Column: 427



    Mr Rajoo: My supplementary question is this. In spite of the centres run by the Government for various languages, will the Minister give an assurance that all schools - whether they are Government or Government-aided or Mission schools - will be made self-sufficient with language teachers to teach the respective language in the school itself, irrespective of the number of children taking a second language?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, wherever there is a sufficient number of pupils taking a second language, a full-time second language teacher will be provided. But if the number of students taking a second language in a particular school is small, for instance, two pupils, surely the Member for Farrer Park does not expect the Government to provide a full-time second language teacher for just two pupils?

    Mr Rajoo: Mr Speaker, Sir, for in, stance, in an English school where there are Chinese, Malay and Tamil children -

    Mr Speaker: Mr Rajoo, I am afraid I must pull you up again. Could you frame the supplementary question?

    Mr Rajoo: Yes. The supplementary question is this. In schools where second language classes are run, during the language period certain children will attend either the Chinese or Malay language classes, whereas the Tamil children in these schools will be left without any teacher, because although classrooms are available, there is no teacher to teach Tamil. That is what I understand. Will the Minister look into the matter and investigate where such a state of affairs exists, so that Tamil-language teachers will be provided and the Tamil children do not waste their time idling during this language period?

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Yes, Mr Speaker, I will certainly investigate if specific instances can be pointed out to me.

    Mr Speaker: In view of the number of questions we have today - it is already five to 3 p.m. - I hope Members

Column: 428

will restrict their supplementary questions so that those who have questions low down in the list will have their questions answered orally. Mr Rodrigues.

Column: 428

SUPERVISION OF KINDERGARTENS


    7. Mr Bernard Rodrigues asked the Minister for Education, in view of the opportunity that can be afforded to anti-national elements to poison the minds of young children, if he will tighten up the supervision of kindergartens or consider bringing them within the state educational system.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, most kindergartens in Singapore are supervised in one way or another by the Government or a quasi-Government organisation. These are private kindergartens registered with the Ministry of Education, those organised and supervised by the People's Association, and creches and play centres organised and supervised by the Department of Social Welfare. Owing to Government supervision of one kind or another, it would be extremely difficult for anti-national elements to poison the minds of young children unnoticed. To date there has been no report of such incidents in these kindergartens.

    However, for quite some time now, the demand for places in kindergartens for pre-school age children has been very great. This results in the establishment of a large number of unregistered kindergartens which fall into three categories: (1) those run by private individuals catering for the upper and middle classes, mainly in the private residential estates; (2) those run by religious organisations in Housing Board Estates or near squatter areas in the City area; (3) those run by political parties, particularly by the anti-national Barisan Sosialis. These kindergartens do not come under the supervision of the Government and are, therefore, open to exploitation by the anti-national elements, particularly so in the case of those run by the Barisan Sosialis in the rural areas. Besides the opportunity afforded them to poison the minds of

Column: 429

the young children in their kindergarten classes, the teachers of these classes and their helpers, who are mostly members of the Barisan Sosialis, very often exploit the opportunity of meeting the parents of these children and putting across their insidious anti-national propaganda. Furthermore, these kindergarten classes also provide a source of income to sustain the livelihood of the Barisan Sosialis members. However, the Government does not favour the negative approach in dealing with this problem by closing down all the kindergartens run by the anti-national elements. To do so would fall into the trap of the Barisan Sosialis who are bound to exploit the issue by accusing the Government of being unsympathetic towards the welfare of the children of the poor living particularly in the rural areas.

    There is a real demand for pre-school education by Singapore parents in recent years as a result of improvement in the standard of living and the awareness of the value of an early education for children. This is, therefore, a social problem which should be better dealt with in a more positive manner. Since 1964, the Government has, through the People's Association, established kindergarten classes in the community centres to meet the needs of the rural parents and to counter the influence of kindergarten classes run by the anti-national elements. By May this year, the People's Association have established 159 kindergarten classes with a total enrolment of 5,900 pupils. The number of classes has since increased to 349 and the total enrolment to 12,500, whereas both the number of classes run by the anti-national elements and the total enrolment have drastically dwindled. Furthermore, a great majority of the kindergarten age children for classes next year have been registered by the People's Association.

    While it is desirable that all kindergartens should be supervised by the Government and be brought under the Republic educational system, the cost of implementing this by way of capital and recurrent expenditure is, however, prohibitive. The

Column: 430

Government, therefore, does not envisage bringing the kindergartens within the State educational system in the foreseeable future.

Column: 430

INTEGRATED PRIMARY SCHOOL IN PUNGGOL


    8. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for Education whether and when an Integrated Primary School will be built in the Punggol Constituency in the vicinity of the 9th or 10th milestone Punggol Road.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, as the existing schools can adequately cope with the present demand for places in primary schools, the Government does not propose to build any new primary school in Punggol Road in the near future. A survey of the demand for primary places in this area shows that the construction of a new primary school is not required.

Column: 430

SECONDARY SCHOOL IN LIM CHU KANG


    9. Mr Tang See Chim asked the Minister for Education whether he is considering building a secondary school in the Lim Chu Kang area to cater for the school children living in that area.

    Mr Ong Pang Boon: Mr Speaker, Sir, investigation is being carried out by the Ministry of Education and the Planning Department for the provision of a secondary school building near the junction of Lim Chu Kang and Choa Chu Kang Roads.

Column: 430

PURCHASE OF LOCALLY-PRODUCED MEDICINES AND DRUGS
(Government policy)


    10. Mr Bernard Rodrigues asked the Minister for Health what is the policy in regard to the purchase by his Ministry of locally-produced medicines and drugs, which are comparable in quality to the corresponding imported articles, when the price of the locally-produced article is higher than that of the imported article.

Column: 431



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Health): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am pleased to inform the Member for Telok Blangah that it is Government's policy to give positive encouragement regarding the use of local products, and in line with the policy a directive was given on the 14th of December, 1965, to all Government departments and statutory bodies by the Economic Development Division of the Ministry of Finance on the subject of preferential purchase of locally manufactured products. To implement such a policy of giving preference to locally-manufactured goods, a preferential price margin of up to 5 per cent of the tendered price of an equivalent imported product is generally allowed. In certain instances, such as the bulk purchase of medicines and drugs, the preference price margin might even be higher.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: A supplementary question, Mr Speaker, Sir, if I may have your permission to break it into three parts?

    Mr Speaker: Is it one question or three questions?

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: A supplementary in three parts.

    Mr Speaker: Can we have the first part first?

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: All right. First, Mr Speaker, is the Minister aware that his Ministry is purchasing P.A.S. tablets from a local factory at $4.38 cents per thousand tablets, whereas the cost of such tablets, after deducting the sales cost, is $4.45 cents per thousand tablets?

    Mr Speaker: What tablets are you referring to, Mr Rodrigues?

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: P.A.S. tablets, Sir.

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: As far as I can remember, the contract was given to a local firm to supply this particular drug at a cost that is much higher than the imported product of the same kind. If the company is going to have very heavy manufacturing costs, I do not think Government is expected to bear the burden. As I have said earlier,

Column: 432

there is already a margin of up to 5 per cent, and, in fact, in medicines and drugs, the preference price margin is even higher, especially in this particular case.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: Mr Speaker, second part - is the Minister aware that S.A.T.A. is purchasing the same tablets at $5.50 per thousand tablets from the same factory compared to the Government's $4.38 cents per thousand tablets?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: I am afraid I have no answer to that, because S.A.T.A. is not a Government institution.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: Mr Speaker, Sir, is the Minister aware that his Ministry is even trying to reduce the price of $4.38 at the moment?

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Lim Kim San): Good for him!

    Mr Speaker: I think the Minister for Finance has answered that question.

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: I did not get that one, Mr Speaker, Sir.

    Mr Speaker: He said, "Good for him!"

    Mr Bernard Rodrigues: Then may I ask the third part of the question, Mr Speaker? What is the Government's policy in patronising local industry?

    Mr Sia Kah Hui: As I have said earlier, there is already this price margin of 5 per cent, and in medicines and drugs the margin is even higher. I do not think there should be no limit to the price that the local company can ask. There must be a limit.

Column: 432

MOSQUITO CONTROL AND ERADICATION IN ANSON


    11. Mr P. Govindaswamy asked the Minister for Health what progress has been made in the control and eradication of mosquitoes in the Anson Constituency.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Chor Yeok Eng) (for the Minister for Health)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I regret to inform the Member for Anson that so far no steps have been taken to

Column: 433

eradicate mosquitoes in Anson Constituency. This is because it is not possible to deal with the mosquito problem of Singapore on a piecemeal basis, as are shown in the results of a field survey without house-to-house checks done on the 24th of November, 1966, in Anson Constituency itself. The results are no less than 107 breeding places, mainly due to mosquitoes breeding in water-bearing receptacles found in scrap dumps of second-hand dealers, water storage tanks in unauthorised dwellings, stagnant water in drains caused by refuse thrown into them by hawkers and residents over a very long time.

    A lot of second-hand goods dealers in this area are responsible for the dumping of discarded receptacles which in turn become breeding places for mosquitoes. This is a long-time process and it is difficult to eradicate the mosquito menace within a short time. The view of my Ministry is that the mosquito eradication scheme can only be effective when it goes hand in hand with the proper reorganisation of the Public Cleansing Service which, I believe Members will agree with me, is to be launched shortly, as well as the licensing and control of hawkers, which campaign has already begun. As we all know, Mr Speaker, the control and the registration of such hawkers constitute a very major part of the Ministry of Health and this work is progressing satisfactorily.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong (Delta)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, a supplementary question on the answer given. I would like to ask the Parliamentary Secretary whether he can implement the scheme as early as possible, because this is the time when the rainy season is around the corner and flooding is coming very soon. I myself have been subjected to the mosquito menace. The breeding of mosquitoes is increasing, and I would like the Minister to implement the scheme as early as possible so that the people of Singapore will be free from the mosquito menace.

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, the supplementary question raised requires me to implement

Column: 434

the scheme as early as possible. That, of course, will depend on our resources. We certainly wish to implement our scheme as early as possible. As I have already indicated earlier, for certain reasons and because of restrictions, we must do some preparatory work in advance before we can do anything else. The mosquito menace is a big problem arising out of various causes and we must have an overall scheme before we can start. A lot of preparation has to be made, and the moment this is done, we shall launch a campaign to implement the scheme. Whether this can be implemented as early as possible will, of course, depend on the question of staff and other resources.

    Mr Ng Kah Ting (Punggol): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. I remember at the last Budget session the Minister concerned replied to my question on this mosquito menace. He did mention that his Ministry was going to set up an Anti-Mosquito Unit. Sir, after a lapse of almost 12 months, I am wondering whether this Unit has, in fact, been set up and whether work has been carried out to eradicate the mosquito menace.

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the question of an Anti-Mosquito Unit was first raised by the Ministry of Health and this Unit has been established. But because of the shortage of staff, the work of this Unit cannot be launched on a large scale. As I have already said, the Public Health Division of the Ministry of Health is now preparing various schemes and is in liaison with the various sections. So when all this preparatory work is done, a proper scheme will be launched.

    Another question about the Anti-Mosquito Unit is that, at the present moment, this Unit has already carried out work in various areas in Singapore on a regional basis. It is not possible to do the work on an extensive basis because of the reasons I have given. So I would like to appeal to Members in this House, as they are very concerned with the mosquito menace, that the

Column: 435

best thing for them to do at the present moment is to start a cleansing campaign in their own constituencies, or an anti-mosquito campaign in their own constituencies. That is more effective at the present moment.

    Madam Chan Choy Siong(In Mandarin): Another supplementary question, Mr Speaker. From the answer given by the Parliamentary Secretary, I would like to ask him a further question on this point. If his scheme cannot be implemented within a year, then do not tell me that the people of Singapore have to be tolerant about mosquito bites for some more time. I appeal to him, as he has already indicated that this problem is actually dependent on the question of staff. Because of the shortage of staff, he says he cannot carry out his work as scheduled. I would like to ask the Minister whether he is prepared to consider employing temporary staff to eradicate the mosquito menace, because if it gets out of hand, then there will be epidemics all over Singapore.

    Mr Chor Yeok Eng(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, this question of the mosquito menace is getting more and more interesting. But it is a question which requires a long time to solve.     The solution to this employment problem lies in a crash programme for the development of export-orientated industries. We must now move to a new phase of the industrial programme, namely, the development of export-orientated industries.
